summary: A try-statement provides a mechanism for catching exceptions.
details: Exceptions can be thrown using a Throw Statement, etc.
At least one handler is syntactically required.
The scope of the variablei is anywhere in the enclosing function.
The variablei is alive precisely during an activation of the enclosing function.
The compiler will automatically reorder the handlers based on their specificity.
A handler X is more specific than a handler Y, if typeX is a subclass of typeY.
static-checks: The variablei cannot share its name with another variable declared in the same scope.
The type of typei must be assignable to type java.lang.Throwable.
No two types in the same try-statement can be equal.

No Disaster.%22);%0A    }%0A    catch (natural : NaturalDisaster)%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22Handle Natural Disaster - %22 .. natural.getClass());%0A    }%0A    catch (storm : Storm)%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22Handle Storm - %22 .. storm.getClass());%0A    }%0A    catch (disaster : Disaster)%0A    {%0A        F::println (%22Handle Disaster - %22 .. disaster.getClass());%0A    }%0A%0A    F::println();%0A}%0A%0Adefun world (x : int) : void%0A{%0A    when (x == 1) then throw new Asteroid();%0A%0A    when (x == 2) then throw new Invasion();%0A%0A    when (x == 3) then throw new Hurricane();%0A%0A    when (x == 4) then throw new Tornado();%0A%0A    when (x == 5) then throw new Volcano();%0A}
